intro: Simira hexandra, commonly known as the African satinwood, is a deciduous tree native to tropical Africa. It belongs to the family Rubiaceae and is characterized by its smooth, light-colored bark and simple, opposite leaves. The plant produces small, white or yellowish flowers that are clustered in umbels, followed by small, red berries. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in lowland forests and along riverbanks. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal uses, it is sometimes cultivated in horticultural settings.
